title: Distributed decision making
description: 今後2回のCatalystラウンドの中で、Catalystコミュニティが分散型の意思決定をより良く行えるようにするには、どうすればよいでしょうか？

f6_assessments.q0:
Improving distributed decision making is key to meeting the Cardano mission of "contributing to the positive advancement of blockchain as a world-changing technology".
I strongly agree this challenge is critical to achieve Cardano's mission.
f6_assessments.q1:
The Distributed decision making challenge existed in Fund 5. There were 6 proposals successfully funded for $96,320 out of $100,000. In Fund 6, there are 20 proposals in the assessment phase for the $75K fund therefore the community has the capacity and likely the interest in funding this challenge up to the $100K of this challenge.
I agree that the Catalyst community has the capacity to address the challenge.
f6_assessments.q2:
The success criteria are relevant to the challenge objectives. The key metrics are mostly relevant to the success criteria. I disagree with the "Re-election rates: if proposers receive subsequent funding, this can be seen as a sign of success" metric since that could also be interpreted as a sign of centralization and entrenching of insiders.
I agree that success criteria and suggested metrics are set correctly to measure progress in addressing the challenge.

f6_assessments.q0:
Distributed decision making


I agree with this proposal being important   because  High-quality and decentralized decision-making, will increase treasury ROI and legitimize decentralized governance. This ensures better transparency, accuracy, more participation and ownership of decisions, less chance of corruption or undue influence, and overall speed of decision making.
f6_assessments.q1: The budget for this project is reasonable .
f6_assessments.q2:
The Verifiability of this is clear. Metrics would include
 
What is the level of Community confidence. What is the avg rating or % of Catalyst members who approve of overall results of a funding round.
WHat is the level of Community participation: What is the number of Catalyst participants contributing to improving Catalyst decision making systems
Measured overall
What is the  Impact of individual initiatives
What is the  Proof of iteration: round over round, is there evidence that "pain points" are evolving? (Failure would look like seeing the same problems emerging each funding round)
What is the  Re-election rates: if proposers receive subsequent funding, this can be seen as a sign of success
What is the  level of Embracing failure and learning from it. - is the community able to see value in & learn from proposals that did not work out?

f6_assessments.q0: Improving the governance system to enable a sustainable distributed decision-making structure is well-aligned with Cardano's mission of improving the systems of the world.
f6_assessments.q1: Since I view this as mostly a matter of structural organization and not a tech missing related problem i believe the Catalyst community has total capacity to adress the challenge.
f6_assessments.q2: I loved the suggested metrics to measure progress, but didn't understand how would be the success criteria for the challenge settle it. I have my own presumptions but i did saw them in the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: Enhancing the Catalyst community's distributed decision making capabilities is critical to the success of this community, but I also think that it has the potential to contribute to addressing the same issues in much broader contexts, up to and including civil society and even humanity.  Scalable, decentralized mechanisms for supporting distributed decision making in novel ways that support diversity and inclusion, and avoid the usual overcentralized mechanisms that so often result in unhealthy and self-perpetuating outcomes is super important!
f6_assessments.q1: Cardano is well placed to support tools for decentralized decision making, so who better than the Catalyst community to tackle these important challenges and provide leadership in addressing them?!
f6_assessments.q2: There is a difficult and self-referential challenge here: how does the community decide whether the community is improving its decision making capabilities?  Therefore it is understandable that many of the key metrics are quite vague, subjective and difficult to assess.  Nonetheless, I think a "bootstrapping" process could be envisaged that would suggest, for example, achieving certain specific metrics in polls run in the usual, centralized and flawed ways, as well as milestones to attempt experiments with better ways to measure outcomes.  Suppose a short-term goal is to achieve a 50+% response rate among some population (e.g., starting with simple telegram or other online polls, maybe moving Fund 7 voters, perhaps one wallet, one vote rather than letting whales dominate, etc.) and for 80+% of respondents to agree that decision making is improving.  That would be a great result, but would not exclude the possibility that 60% of that population is deeply unhappy.  Exactly the kinds of mechanisms that I envisage being developed and explored by funding proposals in this challenge would achieve much better insights into how well the community is improving its distributed decision making.  Fascinating to ponder, so I really encourage the challenge to be established, and more detailed ideas expressed about how to assess progress despite the circular challenges.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal indicates that distributed decision making is a key element to the Cardano mission and indicates high quality and decentralised decision making will increase ROI and legitimize governance. I feel this is a valid ideal to strive for with the caveat that does this mean low quality decision making ought to be excluded. I am inclined to recall the message from the unleashing the crowd literature that suggest quality is less important than engagement quantity even though this appears counter productive to a final quality product.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal represents a very feasible challenge and while it may certainly test the community on some levels its a discussion that warrants our attention. It may even represent a top tier collaborative solution that will define Cardano values such as fairness, inclusiveness and positive change for the world. I envisage many proposers would find this challenge tempting and the range of views we receive may well lead to positive community growth.
f6_assessments.q2: Considering the vast array of proposal directions the challenge will encourage I feel this proposer has done a good job in defining possible success criteria and suggested metrics. The fact is this a topic that the Cardano community needs to have and likely will need to keep having into the future to avoid being dislodged by 4th generation blockchain projects.

f6_assessments.q0:
Decentralized decision making, and incetivizing individual responsibility and accountability is at the heart of Cardano. 
This challenge is very important in my opinion as ADA-holder and a strong sympathizer with the ethos of Cardano, but there is no discussion in the challenge, nor the previous similar challenges, regarding trade-offs and risks with decentralization. Decentralization and distributed decision making is mentioned in the challenge question and why it is important, but not in the definition of success.
Distributed and pseudonomous decision making in a plutocratic proof of stake system like Cardano could skew the measurements in favor of those with the most funds. This would not, in my opinion be in line with the ethos of Cardano, and should be addressed in the proposal.
f6_assessments.q1:
The Catalyst community and Cardano community as a whole has tremedous capacity.
This challenge has been around since Fund 3 (under a different name) but it is not exhibited in the challenge proposal if previous challenges have been successful according to the metrics setup. I have searched various Catalyst sites but not been able to find these metrics anywhere, at least as presented in previous proposals. I have not attended all Townhall meetings where they might have been shared. 
If they have, my mistake, but I would not bet on all voters having attended (or searched the internet for the figures) all the townhalls, so feedback from previous funds would be good to have, to be able to see if we are actually addressing these very important questions.

f6_assessments.q0:
Having a better assessment process, would improve the quality of ideas and proposals. Of interests, the following points should help: Experiments in social, collaboration, or meeting structures that encourage improved decision making. 

Additionally, answer to these questions can help the ecosystem: How do we encourage people to participate in decision making?
How do we ensure the group of decision makers is diverse and accessible to newcomers?

Can you add what experiments will be conducted?
f6_assessments.q1: This proposal is research oriented. Can the proposal include the methodology to conduct research?
f6_assessments.q2: Can the proposal include the exact metrics to gauge success? What is the current data look like? Since this proposal is research oriented, please review the current success criteria.

importance: 質の高い分散型の意思決定は、財務のROIを高め、分散型のガバナンスを正当化します。
success: このコミュニティでは、意思決定プロセスを意識的に改善しながら、献身的で協力的なリーダーのグループを育てています。
